questions.question_text: What type of OS fingerprinting technique sends specially crafted packets to the remote OS and analyzes the received response?

discussion.content: With active fingerprinting the network scanner sends several packets to the target with various settings. The responses to the settings are analyzed and compared to a list of known request/response values to find a match. Operating systems are all built with identifying characteristics within their TCP/IP stacks and configurations. This includes settings such as the TCP window size and TCP initial sequence numbers. Passive fingerprinting also looks at deviations in TCP/IP stack implementations; however it looks for these deviations by analyzing the traffic on the network. Passive fingerprinting does not send any packets to the target; it passively monitors the target’s communications.

choices.B: The host is likely a printer.
choices.D: The host is likely a Windows machine.
choices.A: The host is likely a Linux machine.
choices.C: The host is likely a router.

questions.question_text:
A penetration tester is conducting a port scan on a specific host. The tester found several ports opened that were confusing in concluding the Operating System
(OS) version installed. Considering that NMAP result below, which of the following is likely to be installed on the target machine by the OS? Starting NMAP 5.21 at
2011-03-15 11:06 NMAP scan report for 172.16.40.65 Host is up (1.00s latency). Not shown: 993 closed ports PORT STATE SERVICE 21/tcp open ftp 23/tcp open telnet 80/tcp open http 139/tcp open netbios-ssn 515/tcp open 631/tcp open ipp 9100/tcp open MAC Address: 00:00:48:0D:EE:8

discussion.content:
Ports specific for printing: 
Line Printer Daemon protocol/Line Printer Remote protocol (LPD, LPR). port 515.
AppSocket aka Port 9100, RAW, JetDirect, or Windows TCPmon. port 9100
Internet Printing Protocol (IPP). port 631
TCP 9100 and 631 is used by printers / print servers.

questions.question_text:
An attacker changes the profile information of a particular user (victim) on the target website. The attacker uses this string to update the victim's profile to a text file and then submit the data to the attacker's database.
<iframe src=""http://www.vulnweb.com/updateif.php"" style=""display:none""></iframe>
What is this type of attack (that can use either HTTP GET or HTTP POST) called?

discussion.content: A is correct answer. It’s sometimes possible to store the CSRF attack on the vulnerable site itself. Such vulnerabilities are called “stored CSRF flaws”. This can be accomplished by simply storing an IMG or IFRAME tag in a field that accepts HTML, or by a more complex cross-site scripting attack. If the attack can store a CSRF attack in the site, the severity of the attack is amplified. In particular, the likelihood is increased because the victim is more likely to view the page containing the attack than some random page on the Internet. The likelihood is also increased because the victim is sure to be authenticated to the site already.

questions.question_text: An attacker with access to the inside network of a small company launches a successful STP manipulation attack. What will he do next?

choices.C: He will repeat this action so that it escalates to a DoS attack.
choices.D: He will repeat the same attack against all L2 switches of the network.
choices.A: He will create a SPAN entry on the spoofed root bridge and redirect traffic to his computer.
choices.B: He will activate OSPF on the spoofed root bridge.

discussion.content: In an STP manipulation attack, an attacker connects to a switch port and either directly themselves, or through the use of a rogue switch, attempts to manipulate Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) parameters to become the root bridge. Because the root bridge is responsible for calculating the spanning tree from topology changes advertised by non-root bridges, attackers see a variety of frames that they would normally not see.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the BEST way to defend against network sniffing?

choices.A: Restrict Physical Access to Server Rooms hosting Critical Servers
choices.C: Using encryption protocols to secure network communications
choices.D: Register all machines MAC Address in a Centralized Database
